summary.text_en: Following his 1820 discovery of electromagnetism (`oersted_electromagnetism_1820`), Ã˜rsted also made a major breakthrough in chemistry. In 1825, he became the first person to successfully 'isolate' metallic 'Aluminum' (Al) via chemical reduction. He reacted anhydrous aluminum chloride (AlClâ‚ƒ) with a potassium amalgam and distilled the mercury, leaving behind an (impure) lump of metal 'which in color and luster somewhat resembles tin.' story.text_en: In Ã˜rsted's time, Humphry Davy (`davy_electrochemistry_1808`) had proven 'earths' like alumina were metal oxides, but he had failed to isolate aluminum with electrolysis. Ã˜rsted tried a pure chemical route. He first prepared 'anhydrous aluminum chloride' (a feat in itself), then heated it with 'potassium amalgam' (an alloy of potassium and mercury). The potassium 'stole' the chlorine, 'liberating' the aluminum, which dissolved in the mercury. Finally, he carefully 'distilled' the mercury away, leaving a small, impure lump of aluminum. This difficult process was soon improved upon (in 1827) by Friedrich WÃ¶hler, who produced the first pure aluminum powder.

fun_facts.text_en: In the 1850s, aluminum was so rare and expensive (more than gold) that Emperor Napoleon III of France allegedly reserved his 'aluminum cutlery' for his most honored guests (lesser guests had to use gold).
Ã˜rsted's discovery immediately inspired German chemist Friedrich WÃ¶hler, who in 1827 improved the method (using pure potassium instead of amalgam) to obtain a purer sample.

simple_explanation.text_en: Before 1825, no one had *ever seen* metallic aluminum. They just knew it was 'locked up' in sapphires, rubies, and common clay. Ã˜rsted was the first person to 'pick the lock'. He used a *more reactive* metal (Potassium) to 'steal' Aluminum's 'partner' (Chlorine), thus 'liberating' the Aluminum as a free metal. He only got a small, impure lump, but it was the first time it had ever been seen.
